summary: This 2008 Palm Beach Daily News article reports on a federal judge's review of Jeffrey Epstein's controversial plea deal with state prosecutors. Victims' attorney Brad Edwards seeks to have the deal thrown out, arguing his clients were not consulted. The article details the plea agreement terms, the original police investigation, and the reduced charges Epstein faced.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Palm Beach billionaire and investment banker who pleaded guilty to solicitation of prostitution with an underage girl. He is serving an 18-month sentence under a plea deal being challenged in federal court.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Hollywood attorney representing three girls who claim they were sexually abused by Epstein. He appeared before Judge Marra to argue for throwing out Epstein's plea deal, stating his clients were not consulted.

persons.name: Kenneth Marra
persons.context: Federal judge who is weighing whether to quash Epstein's state plea agreement. He requested more information about the victims' involvement in the negotiations and expressed concern about federal vs. state jurisdiction.

persons.name: Dexter Lee
persons.context: Argued in Judge Marra's courtroom that the federal District Court has no jurisdiction over the plea agreement approved in state Circuit Court.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: One of Epstein's attorneys who could not be reached for comment regarding the federal court proceedings.

persons.name: Guy Lewis
persons.context: Another of Epstein's attorneys who was unavailable for comment at his Miami office.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: His department conducted a nearly yearlong investigation of Epstein. He turned findings over to the State Attorney with a recommendation for felony charges, expressing frustration with the eventual plea deal.

persons.name: Barry Krischer
persons.context: Palm Beach County prosecutor who did not arrest Epstein based on police recommendations, instead sending the case to a grand jury which returned a lesser charge.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Hearing and Incarceration
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty to solicitation of prostitution with an underage girl. He was handcuffed and taken to the Palm Beach County Jail at the conclusion of the hearing.

events.title: Federal Court Hearing on Plea Deal
events.description: Victims' attorney Brad Edwards appeared before U.S. District Judge Kenneth Marra in an attempt to have the judge throw out Epstein's state plea agreement.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department conducted a nearly yearlong investigation that found Epstein paid underage girls for massages and sometimes sex at his mansion.

locations: Epstein's El Brillo Way home (Palm Beach)
U.S. District Court (Southern District of Florida)
keyFacts: Epstein's plea deal called for 12 months of house arrest at his El Brillo Way home and community service after 18 months in jail, with an agreement that the federal government would not prosecute him.
Victims' attorney Brad Edwards argued his clients (three girls) were not consulted when the plea deal was negotiated and that they were about to be named as victims in a federal indictment.

Police Chief Michael Reiter's investigation recommended four counts of unlawful sex acts with a minor and one count of lewd and lascivious molestation, but State Attorney Barry Krischer sent the case to a grand jury which only indicted Epstein on one count of solicitation of prostitution.
Judge Kenneth Marra did not rule immediately but requested more information about the victims' involvement in plea negotiations and expressed concern about federal versus state jurisdiction.
The article quotes Edwards referring to Epstein as a 'serious sexual predator' receiving 'clear, transparent, favorable treatment' and 'using his wealth to insulate [himself] from his crimes.'
